Variation Example: A husband (son) tells his curious wife (mother) of a pretended new law passed by the city council that permits men to have two wives. The wife tells other people & the rumor becomes well known. (Finally all the women of the town want the law to be reversed.)

An old man (farmer, workman, father) decides (is persuaded) to go to school in his old age (because he thinks it will help him become rich). On the way to school he finds a box (purse, bag) full of money. The man who lost it asks the old man if he found such a box, & the old man replies that he found it on the (first) day he went to school. The owner believes that it must have been a different box, because he lost his only recently.

A farmer leaves home to go on a trip with his farmhand, but sends the man back to tell the farmwife not to let a certain man into the house. Knowing that this order will backfire, the farmhand tells her instead that her husband orders her not to ride on a sow. Curious, she disobeys, & the sow bites her on the toe (she falls of & hurts her self). Later on their trip, the farmer & the farmhand hear that a woman in their village was eaten by a sow.

A woman (man) takes a cow (ox, ram, butter, grain) & a chicken (rooster, eggs) to sell at the market. because she misunderstood her husband’s instructions, she sells the cow for the price of the chicken & demands in vain the price of the cow for the chicken. Finally she sells her wares for “what the market will bear” to a customer (Jew) who says he is “the market” & spits in her hand instead of giving her money. Or, she sells without receiving money & adds a pledge (skirt, silver belt, jewelry) or a deposit (a silver spoon). Or, she must go & collect the money herself & is tarred & feathered. She returns home con fused, does not even recognize herself, & tells her hus band what happened. He goes to the town with a fishing rod & pretends to fish in a gutter (well) until the man who cheated his wife passes by & mocks him for being as stupid as his wife. Thus the cheater is exposed & the bargain is undone (renewed).

Classifications: A Woman Does Not Know Herself
Variation Example: To punish his wife for her foolishness (stupidity, drunkenness), a man covers her with tar & feathers (puts a different dress on her, cuts her hair off). No one recognizes her, & even she does not recognize herself (she thinks she is an animal or a devil, asks her children who their mother is).

Classifications: The Husband Hunts Three Persons as Stupid as his Wife
Variation Example: This is a frame story into which other anecdotes about stupid people are set. A man who is exasperated by the stupidity of his wife (bride, sister, daughter) goes out to find three (more) people who are equally stupid. He swears that if he cannot do this, he will leave his wife (beat her, kill her). He finds three such people quickly with out any trouble.

Usually an introduction to other anecdotes about stupid people. A farmer sends his wife to the market to sell cattle (chickens, grain). The buyer tricks her into giving him some free of charge, saying that she should keep the others as the security for his debt (the buyer receives one half of it as credit & owes her the second part).

A stupid woman knows nothing about money. Her husband comes home with a purse full of money & she asks him what is in the purse. He answers lentils (peas, pumpkin seeds, lice, nuts, grain, the plague). Later when he is away, the wife trades the purse with the money in it for something worthless.

Before he leaves home a man tells his wife, “The meat is for the cabbage” (meaning that she should cook them together). The wife follows this advice literally & puts pieces of meat by each cabbage in the garden. When the man sees how stupid his wife is, he leaves her. Usually he goes to look for other fools & meets people who do things even more stupid than what his wife did.

Classifications: A Woman Goes to Get Beer
Variation Example: A woman is sent to get some beer (wine). While she is in the cellar, the meat burns, or the dog takes it & runs away. She chases the dog but forgets to close the tap, & the beer runs out all over the cellar. The woman tries to cover up her mistake by strewing meal on the cellar floor. Or, she throws bread out the window instead of putting it back in the oven, so that the mowers will go home hungry.

Classifications: Woman Must Do Everything like Her Neighbors
Variation Example: A man marries a woman who has no idea how to do housework. He tells her to go to a neighbor & see how she does it. The wife watches the neighbor winnow wheat, scald clothes, & bake bread. She goes back home & winnows flour, scalds her husband’s fur coat & boots, & puts the calf in the oven, etc. Her husband gives her other instructions which she follows literally, with disasterous results.

Classifications: The Stingy Farmwife Gives her Servant some Little and some Big lumps of Sugar
Variation Example: A stingy farmwife offers her servant girl (boy) little or big pieces of sugar, saying that the little ones are sweeter. The servant replies that she is not fond of sweets, & takes the big pieces.
A woman repeatedly cooks a dish for her husband which he does not like. Finally he tells her that he loves it, & she stops serving it to him.

Classifications: Every Hole to Tell the Truth.
Variation Example: (Les bijoux indiscrets.) A man helps a beggar (dervish, soldier) & receives as reward three magic objects, one of which is a stick that makes all holes able to speak. Before the man will marry a woman, he tests her chastity with this stick while she sleeps. Three women (daughters of a merchant, official, & nobleman) fail this test, & the man finally marries an “innocent” shepherdess. The fathers of the rejected women accuse him of slandering their daughters. They are tested again with the stick: the vagina of the first admits that it was unchaste. The second woman stuffs her vagina with hemp, but her anus speaks. The third silences her vagina & anus, but her ear admits to having had premarital intercourse.
The husbands of two women who are quarreling leave them together in a cold place with only one blanket. Since they have to share the blanket, they become reconciled with each other.
A man has two wives, a young one & an old one. The young one pulls out his gray hairs, the old wife his black. They do this until his beard & head are bald.

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms, which appear alone or in combination: (1) A lazy wife lies to her husband, saying that she has spun many spindles of thread. But she always shows him the same spindle. (2) As an excuse for not spinning, a wife tells her husband that she has no reel. He goes to the forest to get wood to make one for her. Afraid that she may have to work, the wife follows him secretly & hides. She calls out, “If anyone cuts wood for a reel, he (his wife) will die”. The man is frightened & goes back home without the wood. (3) A wife tells her husband that the thread she had spun has turned into hemp (has burned, was lost) through his negligence: He should make sure that no birds fly over the house while she winds the thread. If they do, the thread will turn into shreds (be burned up). Or, when the thread is transported in a sack, the spindles disappear (the thread turns into shreds).

A lazy woman (who does not want to spin) complains to her husband that there is no day on which she can work: Monday is rest day, Tuesday is exempt from work, Wednesday is for sleeping, Thursday is for no effort, Friday is Good Friday, Saturday is for bathing, & Sunday is for church.

Three wives wager which of them can best fool her husband. They play various tricks on their husbands, causing them to do foolish things. For example, one wife convinces her husband that he is sick, dead, a dog, a monk, (he retreats into a monastery), a minister (he preaches in a church), or that he should have a healthy tooth pulled. Another wife goes away for a week & convinces her husband it was only for a short time, that while he was absent, his house went elsewhere, or that he is wearing clothes when he is not.

Classifications: Women's Tricks are Better than Men's
Variation Example: A man claims to understand all women’s tricks. A clever woman decides to prove he is wrong. (He makes disparaging remarks about women in the hearing of a clever girl, who seeks revenge.) She makes the arrogant man fall in love with her & tells him she is the daughter of the king. When the man asks the king for the hand of his daughter, the king insists that his daughter is ugly & sick, but the man woos her anyway, marries her, & then discovers that he has been tricked into marrying the wrong woman. On the condition that he keeps her secret, the clever woman helps him out of this difficulty: he should tell the king that he is a Gypsy. The king annuls the marriage with his daughter, & the man marries the clever woman.

A woman appears to eat nothing, but she does not lose weight. This appeals to a miserly man who decides to marry her. After some time he grows doubtful & spies on his wife. Instead of going to work, he hides in a cask (chimney). His mother-in-law arrives, sees where he is hiding, & tells her daughter she should pour hot water in the cask (light the hearth). When the husband re-covers from this injury, he is still distrustful & hides in bed to spy on his wife. His mother-in-law & his wife again know where he is & beat him.

A miserly man marries a woman who pretends to eat nothing. When her husband is away, she eats three chickens (two ducks, a huge meal). When he returns the husband learns how much she ate & becomes sick from anger. On his death bed, he can say only, “My wife, all three (two, every thing)...” The wife (other relatives) hears only “three” (“two”, “everything”) & thinks that he is bequeathing her three things (properties, everything he owns). In Swedish variants a miserly man (woman) becomes sick & sees that the maidservant takes too much to eat. The sick person wants to say that she had taken away everything from him, but can only produce the word, “Everything”, & this is understood to be his final will.

A man dreams that he is in a cave where he has sex with a naked woman. Afterwards, he comes to a place between two mole hills & attempts to relieve himself. His wife wakes him up & berates him, “It is all right for you to have sex with me, but I will not let you shit between my breasts!”
A man who is invited to dinner eats an enormous amount of food. He apologizes for having eaten so little, saying he does not feel well today & that next time he will do better.

Classifications: The Man who Does his Wife's Work
Variation Example: This type is usually a framework into which other anecdotes of stupid people are set. Its basic form is as follows:Following a quarrel in which the husband complains that he works hard while his wife stays comfortably at home, a married couple agree to exchange work. Or, the husband (son) is unable to work outside. His wife (mother) must do the outdoor work for him, while he does the housework. Often, the wife gives her husband instructions about what work he should do. He does not pay attention & wastes half the day resting. The man tries to do several chores at once, & does everything wrong so that he suffers a series of accidents, e.g. he leans over the well while he is carrying the butterchurn on his back, so that the cream falls into the water, he lets wine or beer run out of the cask & throws flour on top of it to dry the floor, he lets the cow graze on the roof, bathes the baby in boiling water, or demands that the pots walk home by themselves, etc. When the wife returns home, she finds that her husband has made a mess & that everything is in chaos. The man admits that he had undervalued his wife’s work, & they agree that both of them should go back to their accustomed duties. Or, the couple do not become reconciled: the wife beats her husband & drives him away.

A husband is hypercritical & nothing his wife does pleases him. In order to give him no grounds for complaint, the wife cooks several dishes for dinner. Each time he objects to what she serves him, she is able to produce a substitute dish. When he grows more & more unhappy, she asks him what he could like to eat. He says, ”I want to eat – shit!” Shortly before, their child had relieved himself on a tablecloth, so she readily gives her husband what he asked for.

A foolish husband is supposed to take care of the animals & the house while his wife is away. A hawk steals one of the chickens, so the wife beats her husband when she returns. When she goes away again, the husband vows to do better. He ties the chickens (and the chicks) all together with a string to protect them from predators. This enables the hawk to steal the whole flock at once.

This misc. type comprises various tales (three subtypes) dealing with a husband who follows his wife’s instructions literally & without thinking. Examples: (1) A husband is so compliant that he hangs his wife, although she had only been trying to test his willingness to obey her commands. (2) A wife (who insists on cleanliness) tells her husband (who has tracked dirt into the house) that he should go away for a while. The husband takes this command literally & goes away for many days. Or, after some time, he sends his friend to ask his wife if he has been gone long enough yet. (3) A husband moves slowly at the request of his wife. Therefore he comes home only at dawn, after her lover is sure to have left.

Classifications: The Woman Cooks the Dog for Dinner
Variation Example: A wife serves her husband cooked dog instead of a pig, because she ate the pig by herself. After the unsuspecting husband has finished eating, he looks for the dog as usual to give it the bones. His wife scoffs at him (tells him a wolf ate the dog).

A jealous husband accuses his wife of adultery and, in order to confirm his suspicions, disguises himself as a priest to hear her confession. Recognizing him, she confesses that she has slept with a servant, a knight, a fool, & a man of God. When her angry husband identifies himself to her, she explains that all of these were himself: at first he served her, then he went to war, then his jealousy turned him into a fool, & now as a priest he has heard her confession.

Hans works for seven years & receives a lump of gold as big as a man’s head as his pay & goes home. Because he finds it too heavy to carry, he trades the gold for a horse, which throws him because he does not know how to ride. He trades the horse for a cow, the cow for a hog, the hog for a goose, the goose for a whetstone, which through his awkwardness falls into a well. Unencumbered but happy, he arrives home.

Classifications: The Mouse in the Silver Jug
Variation Example: A poor married couple bemoans life’s harshness & blame Adam & Eve who through their disobedience & curiosity brought sin into the world. The king (rich man) hears their complaint & invites the poor couple into his house to live in luxury. He stipulates only that they must not open any covered vessel. They cannot resist the temptation & remove the cover from a dish. A mouse jumps out (a bird flies out). The king reproves the disobedient couple & sends them back to their old way of life.

A wife sends another woman to bed with her husband. The husband speaks to her & receives no answer, so he cuts off her nose (hair, braid). In the morning his wife still has her nose, & the husband believes that it grew back through a miracle (that he only dreamed he mutilated her).

(Isolde’s Ordeal.) A (guilty) woman whose husband accuses her of adultery clears herself under oath & by ordeal (wearing a red-hot iron without being hurt) by means of a trick: She summons her lover, who appears disguised as a pilgrim (donkey driver) & carries her from the boat dock to the lawcourt. She makes sure that the two of them fall to the ground (she falls off the donkey) & her lover lands on top of her (sees under her skirt). At the trial, she swears honestly that no one except her husband & the pilgrim (driver) has ever lain on top of her (has ever seen her naked). Because what she swore under oath was true, she is not burned by the red-hot iron used for the ordeal.

A young bride (wife) confesses to her bridegroom (husband) that she has had sexual relations with another man (has an illegitimate child, after her bride-groom had confessed to her that he too has an illegitimate child). The bridegroom complains to his prospective father-in-law (and leaves her). The two men send the mother to the bride to speak to her about the matter, & hide so that they can listen to the conversation. The bride confesses to her mother about her sexual experience (illegit-im ate child). Her mother tells her that she also had lovers before she was married (had three illegitimate children), but never told her hus band about them. (Her husband, overhearing, decides to follow his son-in-law & leave his wife.)

This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a husband who returns home to an adulterous wife, who further deceives him. Examples: (1) While her husband is absent a wife commits adultery with a servant (scribe, farmhand, cook, fisherman). The two are surprised by the husband’s sudden return. The wife tells her lover not to worry & to wait in the garden, & goes quickly to her husband. He suspects something is amiss & asks where the servant is. She sug-gests he should wear women’s clothes & go & look for him. The husband does so & finds the servant in the garden. The servant slaps him & tells him that a woman should not cheat on her husband. The husband is reassured & rewards the servant for his good morals. (2) When her husband comes home suddenly, a wife quickly hides her lover in a chest (featherbed, cupboard, suitcase). A betraying part of his body (clothing) hangs out, & she manages to warn him indirectly to pull it in. Later he escapes.

Classifications: The Husband in the Chicken House
Variation Example: A husband returns home unexpectedly to find his wife with her lover. The wife tells her husband someone is following him & convinces him to hide in the chicken coop (dovecot). She locks him in & spends the rest of the night with her lover. Her husband is grateful that she saved him from the supposed pursuer.

A husband notices that his wife is having an affair. When the lover arrives, the husband catches him & traps him in a chest (cupboard, room). The husband takes the key & brings his wife’s relatives (friends) to show them the evidence. Meanwhile the wife frees her lover & substitutes a ram (donkey, dog, goat). When the husband comes back & opens the chest, the animal jumps out. (He believes that his wife has transformed her lover .) Ashamed, he asks his wife & the relatives to pardon him.

A husband comes home unexpectedly, & his wife quickly hides her lover in a cupboard (under a bed, etc.). (1) (Linteus [the cloth] form.) The wife & her mother spread out a sheet (blanket, sack, trough) that obstructs the husband’s line of vision for a moment, so that the lover can escape. (2) (Oculus [the eye] form.) The husband has only one good eye, which the wife covers on some pretext (kiss, effort to treat either it or the other eye). Often she claims to have dreamed that his blind eye was cured.

A woman has two (more) lovers. When her husband comes home suddenly, she has one of them go outside with his sword drawn, & the other she hides in the house (she stages a struggle). The wife convinces her husband that she gave refuge to a persecuted fugitive. (The husband acts as a mediator.)
